hints_html:
The Riemann sum is given by \(\displaystyle \sum_{i=1}^n f(x_i^*)\Delta x\). What should you use for \(\displaystyle x_i^*\)?

The right-hand endpoints are given by \(\displaystyle x_i = a+i\Delta x = 2+i \tfrac{2}{n}\).

The widths of the rectangles in a \(\displaystyle n\)-rectangle Riemann sum is given by

\(\displaystyle \Delta x = \frac{b-a}{n} = \frac{4-2}{n} = \frac{2}{n}\).
hints_latex:
The Riemann sum is given by
$\displaystyle \sum_{i=1}^n f(x_i^*)\Delta x$. What should you use for
$\displaystyle x_i^*$?

The right-hand endpoints are given by
$\displaystyle x_i = a+i\Delta x = 2+i \tfrac{2}{n}$.

The widths of the rectangles in a $\displaystyle n$-rectangle Riemann
sum is given by

$\displaystyle \Delta x = \frac{b-a}{n} = \frac{4-2}{n} = \frac{2}{n}$.
hints_raw:
The Riemann sum is given by <math> \displaystyle \sum_{i=1}^n f(x_i^*)\Delta x </math>. What should you use for <math> \displaystyle x_i^*</math>?
The right-hand endpoints are given by <math> \displaystyle x_i = a+i\Delta x = 2+i \tfrac{2}{n}</math>.
The widths of the rectangles in a <math> \displaystyle n</math>-rectangle Riemann sum is given by

<math> \displaystyle \Delta x = \frac{b-a}{n} = \frac{4-2}{n} = \frac{2}{n}</math>.
question: 5 (a)
sols_html:
The widths of the rectangles in a \(\displaystyle n\)-rectangle Riemann sum is given by

\(\displaystyle \Delta x = \frac{b-a}{n} = \frac{4-2}{n} = \frac{2}{n}\),

and the right-hand endpoints are given by

\(\displaystyle x_i = a+i\Delta x = 2+i \tfrac{2}{n}\).

Then using the given formulas,

\[\begin{aligned} \int_2^4 x^2 \ dx &= \lim_{n \to \infty} \sum_{i=1}^n f(x_i) \Delta x \\ &= \lim_{n \to \infty} \sum_{i=1}^n \left(2+i\frac{2}{n}\right)^2 \cdot \frac{2}{n} \\ &= \lim_{n \to \infty} \frac{2}{n}\sum_{i=1}^n \left(4+\frac{8}{n}i+\frac{4}{n^2}i^2\right) \\ &= \lim_{n \to \infty} \frac{8}{n}\left(\sum_{i=1}^n 1 + \frac{2}{n}\sum_{i=1}^n i + \frac{1}{n^2}\sum_{i=1}^n i^2\right) \\ &= \lim_{n \to \infty} \frac{8}{n}\left(n + \frac{2}{n}\frac{n(n+1)}{2} + \frac{1}{n^2}\frac{n(n+1)(2n+1)}{6}\right) \\ &= 8\left(1+1+\frac{1}{3}\right) \\ &= \frac{56}{3}\end{aligned}\]
sols_latex:
The widths of the rectangles in a $\displaystyle n$-rectangle Riemann
sum is given by

$\displaystyle \Delta x = \frac{b-a}{n} = \frac{4-2}{n} = \frac{2}{n}$,

and the right-hand endpoints are given by

$\displaystyle x_i = a+i\Delta x = 2+i \tfrac{2}{n}$.

Then using the given formulas,

\begin{align*}
\int_2^4 x^2 \ dx &= \lim_{n \to \infty} \sum_{i=1}^n f(x_i) \Delta x \\
&= \lim_{n \to \infty} \sum_{i=1}^n \left(2+i\frac{2}{n}\right)^2 \cdot \frac{2}{n} \\
&= \lim_{n \to \infty} \frac{2}{n}\sum_{i=1}^n \left(4+\frac{8}{n}i+\frac{4}{n^2}i^2\right) \\
&= \lim_{n \to \infty} \frac{8}{n}\left(\sum_{i=1}^n 1 + \frac{2}{n}\sum_{i=1}^n i + \frac{1}{n^2}\sum_{i=1}^n i^2\right) \\
&= \lim_{n \to \infty} \frac{8}{n}\left(n + \frac{2}{n}\frac{n(n+1)}{2} + \frac{1}{n^2}\frac{n(n+1)(2n+1)}{6}\right) \\
&= 8\left(1+1+\frac{1}{3}\right) \\
&= \frac{56}{3}
\end{align*}
sols_raw:
The widths of the rectangles in a <math> \displaystyle n</math>-rectangle Riemann sum is given by

<math> \displaystyle \Delta x = \frac{b-a}{n} = \frac{4-2}{n} = \frac{2}{n}</math>,

and the right-hand endpoints are given by

<math> \displaystyle x_i = a+i\Delta x = 2+i \tfrac{2}{n}</math>.

Then using the given formulas,

:<math> 
\displaystyle 
\begin{align}
\int_2^4 x^2 \ dx & = \lim_{n \to \infty} \sum_{i=1}^n f(x_i) \Delta x \\
& = \lim_{n \to \infty} \sum_{i=1}^n \left(2+i\frac{2}{n}\right)^2 \cdot \frac{2}{n} \\
& = \lim_{n \to \infty} \frac{2}{n}\sum_{i=1}^n \left(4+\frac{8}{n}i+\frac{4}{n^2}i^2\right) \\
& = \lim_{n \to \infty} \frac{8}{n}\left(\sum_{i=1}^n 1 + \frac{2}{n}\sum_{i=1}^n i + \frac{1}{n^2}\sum_{i=1}^n i^2\right) \\
& = \lim_{n \to \infty} \frac{8}{n}\left(n + \frac{2}{n}\frac{n(n+1)}{2} + \frac{1}{n^2}\frac{n(n+1)(2n+1)}{6}\right) \\
& = 8\left(1+1+\frac{1}{3}\right) \\
& = \frac{56}{3}
\end{align}
</math>
statement_html:
Full-Solution Problems. In questions 4â€“12, justify your answers and show all your work. If a box is provided, write your final answer there. Unless otherwise indicated, simplification of numerical answers is required in these questions.

Using a limit of right-endpoint Riemann sums, evaluate \(\displaystyle \int_2^4 x^2 \ dx\). No credit will be given for the use of antidifferentiation, but you may use it to check your answer. You may use the formulas \(\displaystyle \sum_{i=1}^n i = n(n+1)/2\) and \(\displaystyle \sum_{i=1}^n i^2 = n(n+1)(2n+1)/6\).

statement_raw:
'''Full-Solution Problems'''. In questions 4–12, justify your answers and '''show all your work'''. If
a box is provided, write your final answer there. '''Unless otherwise indicated, simplification of numerical answers is required in these questions'''.

Using a limit of right-endpoint Riemann sums, evaluate <math> \displaystyle \int_2^4 x^2 \ dx</math>. No credit will be given for the use of antidifferentiation, but you may use it to check your answer. You may use the formulas <math> \displaystyle \sum_{i=1}^n i = n(n+1)/2</math> and <math> \displaystyle \sum_{i=1}^n i^2 = n(n+1)(2n+1)/6 </math>.
